docs.lead_paragraph: Angry about General Electric's decision to force employees to pay more for their health coverage, 17,000 workers at 48 locations in 23 states began a two-day nationwide strike today. At the G.E. lighting division complex here, more than 150 strikers picketed in the 20-degree weather to show G.E., the nation's most profitable company, that they would not accept such increases in out-of-pocket costs without a fight.

headline.main: 17,000 G.E. Workers Strike Over Higher Health Costs

docs.abstract: Two-day strike begins at 48 General Electric locations in 23 states, where 17,000 workers are protesting company's decision to force them to pay what it estimates as $200 more a year toward their health costs; officials of two striking unions, which represent 17,000 employees, say cost will be nearly double that amount and say move is unjustified in light of company's strong profits; woman picketing near GE appliance factor in Louisvile, Ky, dies after being hit by police car; photo (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: UNITED ELECTRICAL, RADIO AND MACHINE WORKERS OF AMERICA

docs.lead_paragraph: The Communications Workers of America and Lucent Technologies have reached a tentative agreement on a new 20-month contract to take effect when the current five-year agreement expires on May 31. Lucent said it sought early negotiations on a short-term pact to get a clearer idea of its future labor costs as it struggles to restructure debts that are coming due in the next few years. The union represents 5,400 of Lucent's 5,700 unionized workers. The agreement would give the workers a 2 percent raise in June and another 2 percent raise a year later, but would require them to pay more for most health benefits. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent In Labor Accord
